job_title: Front End Engineer in Boston, MA
pros: Harvard benefits are vast, and range from free products like Adobe Creative Cloud to newspaper subscriptions to popular papers. Getting a bachelor's or master's at the extension school is very inexpensive ($40 a class) for employees. The people you work with are generally very competent and dedicated; can be intimidating at first, but eventually you'll settle in. Work trips and bonding activities are actually really fun, and can give you opportunities to try new things in a relatively safe environment.
cons: Burnout is real. Covid has made WFH the primary option for most of us - which isn't a great fit for everyone. Pay isn't great compared to market rates... which is more of a problem if you don't get use out of the benefits (like taking extension school classes, health insurance, retirement options, etc.). You will probably get a small raise every once in a while (which is sadly more than can be said for a lot of companies), but it won't be anywhere near what you could get from job hopping. Racial diversity is often a big problem; varies team to team, but overall... it's an issue.

review_title: Best work environment, not the best pay
pros:
The work environment is the absolute best. I work under supportive postdoctorate fellows, who are more than happy to help fill my gaps in knowledge and educate me - not only so that I can do the best job, but so I can better myself as a scientist. 

My PIs are fantastic, and there is a large effort put in my the administrative staff to build team morale and make the lab a great place to be. Also, I have great health insurance.

It would take a considerably large amount of money to convince me to leave.
cons:
It's hard to get grants right now. This means that PIs are trying to stretch their grant dollars as far as possible. Where 3-5 years of experience can get you $60k+ per year in industry, 3-5 years of experience here in academic research might get you a very small raise. My colleagues with more experience than me do not make substantially more than me. This probably won't change soon. This means that in spite of how much I like my job, in 3-4 years, I'm going to leave and at least double my salary by moving to industry.

That being said, everyone recognizes that, and most PIs that I know work hard to make the labs in my department a great place to work.

pros: As a postdoc in Harvard, the pros are really dependent on the lab that you join. The biggest advantage is of course the reputation of Harvard on your CV.
cons:
The biggest drawback of working in Harvard is the cost of living in Boston. When I was working in Longwood, I decided that I did not want to live too far from my workplace. I could probably find cheaper accommodations but it would have meant commuting to work and that would incur cost. I decided to use the money I saved on transport to rent a place in Fenway...a 10-minute walk to work. I rented the a room from Harvard in a very nice apartment block in Fenway but the rent was about half of my take-home salary ($1200). So I was literally returning half my salary back to Harvard. 

I felt that Harvard could have offered some subsidy to postdocs renting rooms in Harvard's accomodations considering our salary after taxes and social security was only about $2000. I even wrote an email to the President of Harvard University, Drew Faust. Not only did Drew Faust not reply to my email suggestion. She, in fact, got one her subordinates to find which postdoc had the audacity to send an email to her to voice his grievances and then got Dean of the medical school to get in touch with my supervisor to tell me not to bother her any further. I got a stern warning from my boss to not write to Drew Faust again. The moral of this story is that you won't find much warmth among the faculty in Harvard. In my experience, I have not seen many caring faculty members at Harvard....it is a dog eat dog  world in Harvard and as a postdoc, you are cheap and expendable....if you leave, there are millions who are only too willing to step into your shoes. Therefore, if you value your dignity, perhaps you should pick a job in another place.
